etymology.description: semantic: 艸 ‘grass’ + phonetic: 屯 ‘sprout’ + semantic: 日 ‘sun’; intermediate form 萅; 艸 and 屯 later merged into 𡗗; also used as a variant of 屯 for ‘spring’ in Old Chinese.
etymology.interpretation: Combines grass and sun with the sound-bearing 屯, evoking plants sprouting under sunlight—the essence of spring’s growth. Over time, 艸 and 屯 fused into 𡗗 above 日, streamlining the graph. Early literature sometimes used it interchangeably with 屯 to mean the season of spring.

examples.chinese: 春天的阳光很温暖(春天的陽光很溫暖)。
examples.english: The spring sunlight is very warm.

examples.chinese: 今年春雨很多(今年春雨很多)，庄稼长得旺(莊稼長得旺)。
examples.pinyin: Jīnnián chūnyǔ hěn duō, zhuāngjia zhǎng de wàng.
examples.english: There is a lot of spring rain this year, and the crops are growing vigorously.

examples.chinese: 她正值青春年华(她正值青春年華)，活力四射(活力四射)。
examples.pinyin: Tā zhèng zhí qīngchūn niánhuá, huólì sìshè.
examples.english: She is in the prime of youth, brimming with vitality.
